course.subject: MATH
course.name: Calculus IA
course.description: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.
course.exclusions: Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2; AL Pure Mathematics; AL Applied Mathematics; MATH 1003, MATH 1013, MATH 1014, MATH 1020, MATH 1023, MATH 1024

reviews.author: jimmy5678998
reviews.title: You can learn nothing except hating calculus in this course
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

Yes, correct, but it is not just basic in my opinion. As a student that never have been tapped in calculus, it is already very hard and advanced. (Moreover, I am weak at maths. :( )

It is fairly acceptable before midterm, which only included some basic differentiation and trigonometric identities, (but double angle formulas are as hard as hell for me.) But once you reach the final exam, it is another stuff. The preparation for the final exam took me at least 2 whole weeks to handle well with integration by doing the exercises given by tutorial. And when I tried to do the final exam past paper, I have no idea on how to do the first long question at all! The final exam past paper given is just ridiculously hard and not able to do the long question section. Although the final exam is an open-notes, full multiple-choice question paper due to the epidemic and the difficulty is decreased, it is still challenging for a newcomer to calculus.

The lectures teach you basic theory on calculus with simple examples. While the tutorials give you more moderate exercises. So that you can earn some confidences from them. When the exams arrive, they give you questions with 100% different from what you have done before, so that you have no idea on how to solve them, crash your confidences that you have built before, and your grade is broken.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr Lam is good at teaching and I am fortunate to be taught by him. It is easy to understand the theory with his explanations.  He will solve some webwork questions in class and it is nice. The only problem is the questions taught in class are too easy compared to exam level. And you will find a hard time if you are studying for final exam with just his notes.

Mr Chan's tutorial notes are useful and help me to overcome a lot of basic problems compared to other tutors notes that I have done. Still, the question types are not rich enough on dealing with the exams.

My pals keep complaining about Avery's teaching to me, but I haven't been taught by him, so it is not good for me to comment. Maybe you can try his teaching yourself(or watching other comments are already enough). :)

It is good to point out that I only attended for the first 3 tutorials, then I had skipped all of them, as I feel like the difference is not big if you have finished all the exercises in notes.  While I attended the first 7 lectures because I feel okay and not waste my time. But for the remaining 13 lectures(not included with 7 video lectures after November), I think I have things more meaningful(like playing and studying mahjong) rather than attending them.

TL:DR, don't waste time on things you don't interest in and can't improve your result significantly. JUST SKIPPED THEM ALL ARE STILL FINE FOR YOUR EXAM(as you still don't do well on the exam).
reviews.comment_grading:
if you are good at maths, the course is fine for you. I believe getting A is not that hard for geniuses. Even so, paying more efforts to ensure you to get high enough marks.

If you are bad at maths like me(DSE math level 3~4), you better to be prepared to get C or B- even you did tons of exercises included sources from the internet, you just don't have enough talent to overcome the problem sometimes.

Find some pals that you can work with and good at maths would help you a lot, start studying at least before 2 weeks the exam, and struggle with those who are not good at so you feel less painful when you don't know how to do the maths. B range can be reached if you are determined, but don't think of A, it is just fate if you can't get the thing you hope for.

my score:
Midterm:35/50 (mean: 25.45)
Final: 12/15 (mean: 7.8)
webwork:100% done with 100% mark
I believe I get a B grade. Nevertheless, the grading of this course is shit.
(update: B+ turns out,no A- so sad)

weighing methods:
Method 1:15%(webwork) + 30%(midterm) + 55%(final)
Method 2:15%(webwork) + 85%(final)
reviews.comment_workload:
9 hard webworks
1 challenging and losing-confidence midterm
1 super hard, non-human to do (except this seminar) final exam
That's it.

Not many works to do, except working, studying, revising for final exam two whole weeks without playing any games(including mahjong!!).

Webworks should be finished all and get full marks as you have unlimited attempts, otherwise you will have a hard time on the exams(the question type are some kind of similar and worth to do).
But I think it's fine for those who did well at maths, as they have a clear mind on how to answer them so they do not need to do a lot of works to enhance themselves, I believe. (No offense)

The past paper of 2015 final exam is attached for reference. I think it is extremely hard on long-question section. You can try to do it and decided whether you shall work more or less for better grading.

reviews.author: Smelly
reviews.title: The worst
reviews.comment_content: It was the worst shit of my life. Even though it is a beginner's math class my friend told me there are many things they haven't learnt even in HL IB maths!
reviews.comment_teaching: His lectures are super boring. All he does is write theories and proves them but he never teaches how to solve certain questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Ok grading. I think you can pass with a 30% from what I've heard.
reviews.comment_workload: There is homework every week. About 5-15 questions. The homework is submitted online via webwork. There is an unlimited amount of trials to answer the questions.

reviews.author: Saber Athena
reviews.title: 冇讀過M1/2既入黎聼一聼
reviews.comment_content:
=To Freshmen=
  If you are reading this, it means that you are new to UST and this is likely to be one of your first courses here.
  It is easy to be overwhelmed by the new teaching style.
  It is very important to realize that the teaching quality in HKUST will be nothing like what you have experienced in your secondary school. There will not be people like DickHui or Koopa Koo to help you with your Math. If you rely on the lectures/tutors alone, you will die.

=Contents=
  Covers topics from absolute value, to limits, to differentiation and ending with integration by substitution.
  A lot of the contents are overlapped by HKDSE M2.
  Most of the contents covered in this course, like L'Hopital's Rule and limit to infinity, are direct prerequisite to MATH1014 (Which, if you haven't already realized, is what you will have to take next semester). It is important that you build up a good foundation or else you will die in 1014 (If you haven't already died in 1012)
reviews.comment_teaching:
=Zhang LuChan=
  I don't like criticizing people but her teaching quality is just really poor. It is really difficult to learn anything from her lectures. She reads directly from the powerpoint and makes no effort in explaining the concept. Trust me, you are better off reading the textbook yourself.
  People blame her mainland accent. But having an accent is really not the problem. Her English, though not perfect, are perfectly understandable. The main problem is the lack of passion in teaching.

=Walter Chan=
  Best fcking TA in the world. I mean it.
  Gives good lessons, Genuinely useful. He allows me to understand most of the concepts in the course. Very patient when answering student's questions. You can find him in MSC and ask him if you want to.
reviews.comment_grading:
=Exams=
  The midterm is slightly easier. It contains some typical questions like those you will encounter in Walter's exercise.
  The Exams are not the same. They contains extremely difficult questions, some you have never seen before.
  The Grading is not as bad as 1013 or 1014.

=My Grade=
WebWork: 100% (ish)
Midterm: 42/45
Finals: 10/15
Grade: B+
Meh.

(Reference: DSE Math Core 5*, Never taken M1/2.)
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be heavy workload, there is no questions about it.
  Accept the fact that many students in this class have studied calculus before (e.g. They took it in high school and dropped it.) Many students also have friends to help them with their Maths (Which you don't).
  You cannot get good at Maths in a few days. And you cannot expect to get a good grade if you start preparing a few days before the Exam.
  The only way to survive this is to go to Herman Yeung's channel and watch as many videos as possible. They will provide you with a good understanding of the concept allow you to deal with the difference types of problem. You can also check out Organic Chemistry Tutor or Khan's Academy's videos, although they tend to be on the easier side.
  Work of warning: Integration is very difficult to understand so prepare AT LEAST 1 month before the exam if you are seeking an A range.
  I don't really recommend reading the textbook as the style of writing is boring and technical. You will get confused and lost easily (Although the textbook proves to be pretty useful in 1014)
  Doing exercises is a must. You can start off by doing Walter Chan's exercise (Or those provided by the other tutors). You can also go do those in 中大出版社's M2 textbook IF YOU HAVE TIME. Try to not spend too much time on one specific topic.
  Lastly, go find Walter Chan for help if you have any question.

-Saber Athena

reviews.author: leon czolgosz
reviews.title: WELCOME TO HELL
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus my ass
Heard this is 2 years of M2 in one semester.

Week 1: Number, inequalities and absolutes, basic functions and graphs, composite functions Week 2: Exponential functions, trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions
Week 3: Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws
Week 4: Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change
Week 5: Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions
Week 6: Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions
Week 7: Rates of change problems, related rates
Week 8: Maximum and minimum values
Week 9: Derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule
Week 10: Curve sketching, optimization problems
Week 11: Antiderivatives, areas
Week 12: Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Week 13: Indefinite integrals and net change, the substitution rule

As an idiot who dropped out of M1 after learning limit (basically I know nothing about calculus) and got 4 in Math core (yes I’m stupid, I only got here because English weighting*2), this is too much for me. I survived by watching the zoom recordings at 1.5 speed, going to tutorial and supplementary class, and watching youtube videos. Definitely study before hand and do exercises.

I found these sites by Math TAs from earlier messages:

Mr Walter Chan:
https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/2020-fall?authuser=0

Ms Phyllis Liang:
https://masxliang.people.ust.hk/
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Qian is ok. He’s from the Mainland, but his English is understandable. His notes are ok, with clear and very nice handwriting. He uploads them onto canvas afterwards after some classmates requested them. He includes a lot of math proof in his lectures/notes, which was confusing for an idiot like me.
As this is a zoom class, he wants everyone to be quiet and watch him write notes. He will answer questions in class if you ask, but someone asked him a question and he said it was too easy. I did not ask questions as I don’t even know what to ask.
Unfortunately, I am a dumbass. I started crying when we got to sum-to-product rule of trigonometric functions or something and gave up and just watched the zoom recordings. And then I felt horrible because it was a bit disrespectful. Curse my Asian upbringing.
TA Henry Tsang is great. Taught us how to do webwork and explained stuff.

Just go to tutorials and supplementary classes. And watch youtube.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% webwork
75% final exam
FUCK YOU ASSHOLES HOW AM I SUPPOSED TO KNOW WHAT I’M DOING WRONG/POSSIBLE IMPROVEMENTS
AT LEAST FOR MID TERM IF YOU FUCK UP YOU CAN WORK HARDER IN FINAL
THIS IS LIKE DSE ALL OVER AGAIN
FUCKING SADISTS
Honestly, for webwork, I think everyone can get full marks, just go to the math support centre if you don’t know.
Webwork:100% (Thanks Math support and other people)
Final Exam: 59% (plus 2 marks thanks to TA Henry) Mean: 42.17%
2 hours, 10 long questions this year, before there were MC.
As long as you do steps/draw diagrams/mention fundamental theorem of calculus/L Hopital/discoveries of other geniuses who have way too much time on their hands, you get points for trying.
Final Grade: 69.25% A- Mean: 54.75%
I really did not expect myself to do that well lmao
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork every 2 weeks, until the end of the semester where it’s once a week. 9 in total.
Unlimited attempts.
Maximum questions I’ve seen were 19, usually most of them are around 10-13.
Acceptable. Just go to Math support. The TAs are great. Or use Symbolab or Wolfram Alpha or other online calculators.

reviews.author: Wolfheart
reviews.title: This course is an injustice
reviews.comment_content:
Personally, I studied Maths SL in IB. Most of the students in the course studied DSE and may have had a different experience than I had.

The content up to the midterms consisted of limits and basic knowledge on derivatives. The difficulty was okay. All content on derivatives was covered in IB, and I had to learn about limits, mostly through Khan Academy, practicing past papers, and asking my peers.

Finals suddenly got a lot more difficult and required studying to catch up, especially with the pace of how frequently Webworks were released. This is also where the part on word problems are introduced, and personally, in my opinion, those types of questions just required a degree of creativity to answer.

Warning: This course will truly foster your HATRED for maths in the future. The effort required for most people is disproportionate to the outcome of this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery tries to be funny in his class, but he ends up acting silly. Despite his jolly personality during class, do not be deceived by how sadistic he is for the midterm and final exam of this course. People complain about his English and some may complain about his heavy accent, but given that this is a math course, I believe that his message is usually clear. His e-mails are written like a kindergartener though, but they inspire fear in you when you receive it as he often includes the mean and SD of the relevant assessment in the e-mail.

Lectures are generally useless and skippable. There is a decent chance that you may doze off or fall asleep. Watching Khan Academy or videos from similar people would be more helpful in understanding contents of the course. Practicing solving and doing homework has actually taught me more than attending class as well.

I didn't utilise the help of the T.A., Walter, but he seems to be friendly in tutorials. I also did not ask for help from the Math Support Centre because consulting them through an online environment would've been unnecessarily difficult, so I cannot comment on my experiences with the two parties.
reviews.comment_grading:
For this semester, the course has two grading schemes:
Scheme 1 - 15% Webwork, 30% midterm, 55% finals; or
Scheme 2 - 15% Webwork, 85% finals

Avery then chooses the higher grade produced by the two schemes. I'm not sure if the course used absolute grading like its sibling course, MATH 1013, but since the SD and mean of the midterm and final grades were given, it was probably curved.

Now, for the gravely unjust grading system:
15% Webwork: 93.33% (mean: 93.8%; I forgot to submit on one week)

55% Final: 11/15 (mean: 7.1 based on Canvas)
30% Midterm: 40/50 (mean: 24.2, SD: 11.9)
or
85% Final: 11/15 (mean: 7.1 based on Canvas)

Final Grade: 78.33% (mean: 61.6, SD: 20.5) under Scheme 1
B+

Roughly 0.75SD above for a B+. I have a friend who scored exactly 1SD above and also received a B+.

I can't imagine what the letter grade for mean or below mean is. To my knowledge, 1 SD above should receive an A-.

Furthermore, the grading of scheme 2 was absolutely illogical and stupid. This fall-term arrangement for finals had 12 multiple-choice questions overall -- 10 questions worth one point and 2 questions worth 2 points. Each student had two attempts to do the exam on Canvas. Let me just rant about how I did the computation and losing just one point was equivalent to a 5.x% decrease in the final grade.

The printed final examination (based on the sample final) includes questions on a broader range of topics and is more indicative of one's level of understanding of the course.

Combining the preposterous and overwhelming weight of 85%, along with the disappointing letter grade, you get MATH 1012.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is Math homework on the Webwork platform that is released weekly and accounts for 15% of the final grade. Make sure to do the homework and try to score 100%. Set up a weekly reminder if you have to. If there's a question you've been stuck on, don't be afraid to search for the answer on Google or use software like Wolfram Alpha. It's not worth it to end up forgetting about the homework entirely.

As for the midterm and final, Math is all about practice. The lecture notes generally provide a complete overview of what you need to know. It isn't enough though, and you should definitely practice on past papers to get a feel of the exam structure and adequate pacing.

MATH 1012 barely has any past papers. Throughout the course, students were provided only the 2015 version of the midterm and finals. In contrast, you should practice on MATH 1013 past papers. The syllabus is 90% similar to MATH 1012, with topics like linear approximation and Newton's Iteration Formula being two of the concepts excluded from the MATH 1012 syllabus. However, questions in MATH 1013 are harder, so if you are able answer them, MATH 1012 will suddenly feel easier. In addition, MATH 1013 has more sets available online with dates from 2012-2016, although not all of the exams have solution sets available to them.

As for the midterm of this course, it was very similar to the sample MATH 1012 midterm provided to us. The breakdown of the questions by topic were almost the same -- long questions included a topic on limits, derivatives, and graphing. Multiple choice also contained questions that only had their values changed.

reviews.author: Vanessayuuu
reviews.comment_content: 中學冇讀過M2嘅人先會入呢個course，但讀既嘢同MATH1013中學讀過M2嗰班差唔多，所以係超級難！本身數學差既人係完全唔會明教緊咩做緊咩。要好認真清concept，要跟上進度，先會讀到。
reviews.comment_teaching: 勁差，超級悶。上學唔會學到嘢，只會恰眼瞓。
reviews.comment_grading: 冇努力清concept，所以F左。
reviews.comment_workload: 要上網做webwork，每次有十幾題。每隔一兩個星期一份，總共有有十幾份。

reviews.author: Jane Swift
reviews.title: Good if you like self-learning
reviews.comment_content:
The book is J. Stewart, “Calculus Early Transcendentals,”  7th ed.

1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), L’Hôpital’s rule (4.4)
10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching: really bad, I didn't listen to him after a month. no use at all, so I end up self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 25%, final examination: 75%
fair, I did not get full mark in homework, and got 90/100 in final, end up A+.

The homework has unlimited chances before the ddl, I miss the point because of forgetting to do it.
reviews.comment_workload: light, the available time is enough.

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: Self-learn and being proactive is compulsory, don't rely on prof
reviews.comment_content:
As is known to all, this course covers basic calculus concepts, namely limits, derivatives (optimisation, rates) and integrals. Elementary topics such as trigonometry and functions are also to be discussed.

The content itself is quite difficult to consume for students with zero M1/M2 background like me. Yet, if you are willing to do more exercises provided by TAs, I'm sure it won't be too overwhelming for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The 'E' is for the all-mighty Avery. To do him some justice, he seems like a kind guy. But you don't need to attend Avery's lessons because attendance is not counted. Another main reason is that his lectures are subpar, and his notes are utterly messy. He provides proof for each equation which are unnecessary and time-consuming, and I'm sure you have all seen his bad comments everywhere, whether of UST space, LIHKG or goop. Many people complain that he speaks ~10 'uuuhhhhs' in each sentence, but I don't think it really matters, because he's in MATH department, right?

I strongly suggest you revise TA's notes, which are neat and useful. For starters, you can see Phyllis Liang's notes, which can be found by searching her name on google. As for more question types, you can check out Walter Chan's notes, which can also be found on his google site.

btw, although Phyllis' accent is mainland-ish, her notes and lectures are highly useful, so do attempt (personally, I'm from Phyllis' group. She teaches in a slower pace which I like); Though Walter speaks in a prompt manner, he is experienced and I often find him during MSC hours because it's better for me to ask in Cantonese. Two great tutors that I strongly recommend if you are eager to improve.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got an A eventually.

webwork 25%
finals 22 marks ->  75%
However I have to point out that the percentage distribution is super shit. It is basically an all-in finals course.
reviews.comment_workload:
First off, don't be scared by the credit that this course carries, because it is not accurate (some 2 credit courses are so chur)

The good thing for 1012 is that the online homework assignments, which is done in a system called webwork, allows students to have unlimited attempts, while 1013 only has 5 attempts per question. Thus, you should get a full 25% if you do it.

Why I gave the workload a C is that it requires time to get to know the concepts of different topics. A good way to do it is to review TA's notes, which are listed in the 'teaching' section above.

If you have any questions, feel free to ask! Glad to help

reviews.author: dansonmak
reviews.title: EASY TO HANDLE
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The examples given in the lecture are important for the mid term and final.
In fact, you can skip most of exercise if you understand those examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% mid-term
15% webworks
50% final
overall ~81 and i got an A in this course
reviews.comment_workload:
9 webworks
1 mid-term
1 final

reviews.author: PrayForPaff
reviews.title: 知己知ddx, 百戰百勝
reviews.comment_content:
limit and continuity (continuity這些概念不會重點考，但是也需要知道，最重要知道limit這些怎樣計算）

differentiation:
chain rule, ddx of trigonometric functions and inverse functions and exponential and logarithmic functions, implicit differentiation, rate of change
(記得要學好不同種類的ddx如何計算，重要！！！！）

applications of differentiation:
Max/min values, concavity, L'Hospital's rule (limit剋星，解決limit變得超容易！）,Curve sketching, optimization
(Optimization少考，通常curve sketching都會出一大題。newton's method, parametric curves不考，根本沒有教）

部分的integration:
Reimann Sum, fundamental theorem of calculus, indefinite integrals
(除了reimann sum, 以上的内容都略教）

内容不覺得好多（當然可能因爲我早接觸），最重要還是要厘清概念，有不懂的儘快問math center/其他人，有問題不要不問，因爲integration的概念是基於differentiation，differentiation的概念又基於limit, 互相有關係，所以如果一開始的limit學不好，真的要努力追上，否則後面的概念更加學不懂。
reviews.comment_teaching: 課堂上略嫌他英文口音，真的真的非常影響課堂上概念的理解（其實想說不如用普通話教反而我可以catch up）所以強烈建議如果聽不明白就找herman yueng，他可以carry到你至少mean。還有，有時候因爲講起數學某概念的時候會講起關於他家人的那些東西，個人覺得沒所謂，不過可能會混亂學生的思維（因爲摻雜了其他不重要的信息）。如果克服了他的口音之後，會發現他也會很嚴謹地解釋概念，無論limit也好ddx也好，質素上不錯，但是口音真的是一個扣分點
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 8HW, all 100/100
mid-term: 72/100 mean: 35.62
final: 100/100 mean: 60.14
resulting score: scheme 1: 91.6% scheme 2: 97.2% mean: 63.53%
grade: A+

分兩個scheme, scheme 1是assignment 20%，mid-term 30%，final 50%
scheme 2是assignment 20%，mid-term 10%，final 70%（可能因爲mid-term全部1012的學生都die了，我也承認mid-term卷的難度比final更難）final分兩份卷，有AB卷，選一份來做，我做的是A卷。（這裏就不提供past paper了，我剛剛在peter gao上載了mid-term跟final卷，我只拿到mid-term卷的答案， final卷是我手寫，因爲根本沒有電子檔，我考完數學之後一天根據我的記憶寫出來的，final的答案有部分是我附上的，其他答案敬請去wolfram alpha / geogebra 求證）


我覺得我拿A+部分原因是我post-DSE之後去事先接觸微積分（利申：沒有讀M1/2，數學core拿5，沒有5*超可惜）主要透過Herman Yueng認識limit，ddx等概念，我記得我開學（1/9）的時候，我自學M2到大概ddx,還沒有步入application of ddx, 不過這個已經提供了一個很好基礎去理解Hu Jishan的課堂，否則我覺得我這個1012也會go die X_X

還有，善用Peter Gao的past paper，tutorial給的練習跟classviva海量的練習，他們真的很有用，幫你矯正概念+明白題目想你回答什麽，趁早去練習愈好。
reviews.comment_workload:
大約2星期發一次功課，但其實我覺得workload還算剛剛好，通常一做就大約2小時，如果快+容易的話甚至1小時（可能是因爲我本人讀的比較多course, 其他course幾乎都是一個禮拜一份功課的時候，突然來一份數學功課的時候會崩潰o(≧口≦)o）。功課在classviva做，有無限次attempt，而且如果有些題目不會做的時候，可以有whatsapp / math center幫忙，甚至classviva裏面有給練習（附答案+解答步驟），而功課裏的題目有時候跟練習的題目類似，基本上如果會做練習的話功課都會做。

不過有一點不好的是intergral的部分，因爲進度問題，Mr Hu在lecture有提到不會在final考，但是偏偏要求要做integral的功課（而且功課會算進你的final score，課堂上沒有教授做這份功課需要的技巧，需要靠herman yueng + 其他YouTube資源）他解釋說是math center 的決定，也是沒辦法╮（╯＿╰）╭

reviews.comment_teaching:
Terrible pronunciation. It's hard to know what he's talking about.
His class is super boring. All he did was write theories and prove them, but he never taught how to solve certain problems. Proving theory is pretty useless for this course, and doing so is a waste of time.

reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload for those who never studied M1/M2. Which is me :(

reviews.author: Raniaska
reviews.title: Very brief introductory course for calculus!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Calculus concepts:
Functions
Limits
Differentiation
Integration
Just check the syllabus for the topics and teaching schedules.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor QIAN is a pretty decent instructor, you can clearly understand what he is saying and doing. With his hand-written notes filled with concepts and examples, I believe revising them a bit after each lecture is a good way to improve (which ironically I defo did not do that because I'm lazy :>). If you are paying attention in class, it's not too tough for people without any calculus background.

As for my TA Henry, his voice is depressing af but somehow makes me enjoy his tutorials and supplementary lessons because of it. He is very responsive to students' questions during classes and is actively trying to help us learn calculus. Sometimes his silly moves makes it even more enjoyable, I'm glad that I came across him.

Nothing related to HKUST but Khan Academy and Organic Chemistry Tutor helped me a lot to clear up calculus concepts so definitely go check them out!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading (from what I heard). I got 69/100 in finals and 77% in total (With all homework sets completed).

I must say I never thought my first ever grade will be an A- , considering that I have never studied HKDSE m2 but still managed to pull off a good grade is really surprising.

Final mean: 41.9/100
Total mean: 54.55%

It's pretty fair to say that if you completed all your homework sets on webwork, you would at least get C+ to B- , depends on how well your final exam is. I think the final is rather easier than the past papers, with 10 short / long questions only.

Grading method:
Homework: 25%
Final Exam: 75%
reviews.comment_workload:
New homework set on webwork every week with each having ~2 weeks before deadline. Some questions are easy while some are difficult. My TA asked which questions we needed help in every tutorial lesson and solved them one-by-one for us. So if you need help, just attend the tutorials (or search the answers on google if you want :> ).

Oh btw, this course allows unlimited attempts to submit homework answers so you could try as many times as you like before the deadline. :)

reviews.author: Ckwan
reviews.title: 難
reviews.comment_content:
課程主要覆蓋大部分的中學M2內容, 另外也有一些延伸部份, 可以參考其他人的留言
基本上等於兩個多幾月內學習別人在中學學習三年的內容再包含一些延伸, 對於中學未接觸過M2加上數學底子不好的人, 例如我, 就會感覺非常吃力

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs
Week 2 Elementary functions
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; The limit of  a function and limit laws
Week 4 Continuity; Limit at infinity; Limit definition of derivative and rates of change
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; Differentiation rules.  
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values. (Critical Points)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems
Week 11 Antiderivatives; Areas and distance travelled
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
Week 13 Net change; Substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
因為未接觸過加上數底不好, 我覺得他教得有點太快了, 一開始還好, 慢慢變成上今天的課温上一課的內容, 然後再慢慢跟不上直接走堂, 但不是他學的不好, 只是我自己的問題, 他的筆記都是很整潔清晰而有用的, 我靠上tutorial跟上後都會再看看他的筆記
Btw tutorial的筆記和題目真的沒法比, 筆記全都會, exam還是滿江紅
reviews.comment_grading:
感覺很多人都已經學會calculus再來這裏虐渣, midterm mean 24.2/50 sd 11.9 total mean 61.6 sd 20.5
兩個各低一個sd C
reviews.comment_workload: 一至兩週一Webwork, 每次十多題, 很輕鬆, 也感謝以前的師兄姐, 在網上已經為我們拿到不少解題方法和標準答案

reviews.author: averychingrocks
reviews.title: One of UST's easier courses *FINAL EXAM ATTACHED*
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs. (Basically pre-calculus knowledge - high school stuff but know the fundamentals)
Week 2 Elementary functions
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values. (Critical Points)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule

The content was very doable since I learnt more than half of it in IB SL Math so I only had to study Limits, L'Hopitals Rule, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Riemann Sums. Also, I had to get used to the university style questions as they require more thought than high school questions. Study Avery's long note documents as the exam questions are very similar to that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly, Avery is one of the smartest professors I have seen in HKUST but being completely honest, he can't teach. He says "uhhh" half the time and goes about solving questions in a way which I am not used to. Don't worry if you don't understand his methodology. There are much easier ways to do the questions. Alternatively, you can turn to YouTubers such as Khan Academy or PatrickJMT who are able to teach you the content in a brief and concise manner. But as aforementioned, his note documents are the key to success in his class. Do make sure you can do every question.

However, do go for Phyllis's tutorials. She is one of the best TA's in the math department and her notes are so jeng. She has everything one must know for the topic and all sorts of difficulty of questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was pretty decent. There were two grading schemes.

Scheme 1:
15% Webwork (Homework) + 30% Mid-term + 55% Final Exam

or

Scheme 2:
15% Webwork + 85% Final Exam (for those who could not do the midterm due to the social unrest and special situation)

My grades:
100/100 for Webwork (Unlimited Attempts)
38/50 for Mid-Term (Mean was 26.7 and SD was around 11)
15/15 for Final Exam (Mean was 8.67)
Overall: 92.8% (A+)
*The overall mean was like 61.6 with an SD of 20.5
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was honestly not that heavy. I just used to do briefly look over the content since I knew the majority of it and did some practise questions to solidify my knowledge. However, if you have no background to calculus, the concept did take me a while to understand in high school so don't be afraid if you don't understand it right away.

reviews.author: Andy HK
reviews.title: won't understand without a close friend or tutor to teach you
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I enrolled in the class taught by Wang Erxiao but I completely could not understand what he said and attending his lecture was useless. But he would review the mid-term and final exam past paper 2-3 lessons just before the exam, which was an advantage because the course coordinator did not do that, so it is suggested to attend these lectures even if you skip regular lecture.
I attended Avery Ching's lecture from time to time because I would like to try the coordinator's lecture.  I failed to understand the content as well but I could still get the meaning sometimes, and at least learn something. Avery Ching did not provide lecture ppt and all the notes were in hand-written format during the lesson.
One advantage of Wang ErXiao was that his lecture notes were well-organized, so I could self-study by reading his lecture notes, and learn from the example.
reviews.comment_grading:
WeBWorK Online Homework: 15% (Mean is 90%)
Midterm Exam : 30% (Mean is 30/50)
Final Exam: 55% (Mean is 25.85/60)
I got 35/50 in mid-term exam, 15% for webwork, final exam score is not released. I got B+ finally.
I would like to share my story here. Normally, all students taking this course are year 1 but I took this course in year3 the first time because of some reasons. I was afraid of this course since the first semester in year1 until I got a unexpected grade finally. The content was definitely terrible and unacceptable. I have a twin brother studying at UST as well, who got B+ in this subject too. He has studied M2 in high school but dropped it in form 5. He said math1012 content required 2 years to be taught in secondary school. But we need to learn both form4 and form5 knowledges within 3 months.
If it had not been for my twin brother who taught me the math1012 content in advance, during the winter break and summer holiday in year1 and year2, I must not be able to pass this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The webwork exercises were extremely difficult and time-consuming. Many of the exercises were done by my brother. I also went to math support center to ask for some questions. But some of the tutors in math support center were a little bit arrogant and inapproachable. The attitude of one tutor who is a bit old was extraordinarily poor. When i was talking to another tutor who taught the tutorial of my session, the old tutor suddenly joined the conversation and his tone and content seemed like punishing me. Fortunately, there was a student helper who taught me patiently every time. I remember he needed to be on duty for 2 hours that day, he spended 2 hours to answer my questions and i understood the questions of the past paper completely. Otherwise, i would not ace the final exam. I was exceedingly grateful for his help but I don’t know how to contact him and thank for him, which is a pity.
A suggestion for you is that for a few sets of exercises concerning the calculation of differentiation, limit and integration, you can surf the internet and type differentiation calculator, limit calculator and integration calculator to help you get the answer if you don't know how to do or have no time.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Speaking from the experience of being in L3: Tu Xushan has the hardest accent I've ever heard and I couldn't understand what he's trying to say; Like, he pronounces Theta as "c-tart", and mean as "meme", yeah, go figure

If you have friends in 1013, go to sit their lectures instead, you'll probably learn more from there along with YouTube University (Check out Oscar Cheung's playlist from SSci, he's pretty good)

The only saving grace for 1012 is that they have tutorial sessions by TA's that literally teach better than the professors, Phyllis Liang is great and her tutorial sessions are worth going to unlike the actual lectures
reviews.comment_grading:
Per the words of Tu Xushan in the group chat after the midterm grade was released: "most students are between 10-35%, and L1-L4 are almost the same"

Marks in the midterm are distributed as 40% MC and 60% LQ, 4 MCQs worth 10 marks each, and 3 LQs worth 20 marks each, literally get lucky with 1 MCQ and you'll already be ahead of a good number of people

Midterm mean for L3 is 29.2/100, SD 24, the distribution curve was literally an L shape, this is accurate because what we take here at 1012 are L's and no W's. Like wtf is this LOL

reviews.author: Spongi Bobu
reviews.title: This course will be your first course to skip lesson
reviews.comment_content:
This is NOT an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, 100% NOT designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus. This shit is not basic at all, its a forking torture, but its a must to take this course

1. Derive the inverse function of a given function
2. Limits (xc→  and x→)
3. To show the existence of a root by using the intermediate value theorem
4. Find the derivative from the definition
5. Chain rule
6. Implicit differentiation and tangent line
7. Rate of change

reviews.author: Regginton
reviews.title: ye what the fuck bro
reviews.comment_content:
As a IBDP SL maths student, this course is exactly like HL maths (AA not AI), tbh even if u dont know all the rules for the extended parts of derivatives or integrals dw, its all just chain rule and quotient rule (you just need to be proficient with the basics). Its not hard but also not easy.

course content:
1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), L’Hôpital’s rule (4.4)
10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery has a strong Hong Kong accent, it may be quite intimidating for students as he said many 'ah, er, la'
He mainly focuses on proofs and steps of the examples, however, the examples he lists were too basic compared to the exam ones.
TA (Zeta) was impeccable in his teaching, his examples were relevant to the exams and were well-explained
reviews.comment_grading:
WeBWorK Online Homework: 15%
Midterm Exam: 35%
Final Exam: 50%

Webwork's help could be sought from MSC, pretty guaranteed a 15 % from the grade.
Final was much harder than mid-terms and have a lower mean, ~40%, while mid-terms have a mean ~50%.
reviews.comment_workload:
The content would get harder over the course, hence constant effort are needed.
Lectures did not require attendance, but I recommend to go to the lectures if the understanding of concepts were not clear.

reviews.author: erika.s
reviews.comment_content:
Intro to calculus. Topics include: Functions, Limits, Derivatives, Optimization, Integration.

Midterm mostly tested limits and final was predominantly on derivatives and integration. Make sure to know your graphs because both exams have long graph sketching questions.

Final is all inclusive, including midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is extremely bad at explaining, heavy accent, makes easy concepts very complicated.

It's better to skip lectures (No attendance, so its ok) and study lecture notes by yourself, with help from youtube videos e.g. Khan Academy to understand concepts rather than go to lectures and try to understand the professor.

TAs are more helpful, especially Dave. Be sure to go to tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Harsh grading for an 'intro' to calculus, make sure you do well in midterm. Final is harder to score in so get a better mark in midterm. However overall, it's very hard to fail the course if you have done higher mathematics in high school and have a solid background in calculus.

Webwork: 15% of overall grade, can easily get full 15%
Midterm Mean: 28.5/50, 35% of overall grade
Final Mean: Unknown, 50% of overall grade

I scored below mean for both midterm and final, got C for 46% in the course overall. Hard to fail this course, so as long as you study well and are good at math, an A is definitely possible.
reviews.comment_workload:
High workload, webwork every week. Although webwork is not of high difficulty, and solutions for most questions can be found online if you absolutely have no idea how to solve them. Webwork has unlimited attempts, so very easy.

TA gives additional practice problems, if you choose to do these, then the workload is extremely high.

reviews.author: Jonas Lee
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus. The concept is entirely new for students without HKDSE M1/M2 experience.
Includes limit, differentiation, integration.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's teaching makes the course hard to follow. I am not a math head and didn't know what he was teaching half of the lecture.

TA Zeta Chan was very helpful. He explained the steps and reasoning very well in tutorials and provided adequate exercise for us.

I gave up after 2 weeks and didn't attend the lectures very often. I went to all the tutorial and finished all the tutorial questions by myself.

I think watching khan academy is adequate for everyone to understand the course content. There is no need for attending the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall 70% Graded B
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends.
Webwork was quite easy and had only 9 throughout the whole sem.

Tutorial notes from Zeta had many questions, but it is optional. Finishing them all will make this course a heavy workload.

Overall, this is not a heavy workload course.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Not only is his accent difficult to understand, but his teaching style may not be suitable for everyone. He assumes that you have some basic knowledge of calculus and focuses on teaching you how to prove formulas.

As a beginner, you may find this method unhelpful for understanding the material. In that case, it may be best to SKIP SKIP SKIP the lectures.

On the other hand, I found the tutor's notes and teaching style to be very helpful in MATH1012, along with resources such as YouTube. I strongly recommend blackpenredpen youtube channel which help me survive in the exam :)


Good Luck to all see till the end ~
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading method

1) 0.3 mid term, 0.3 hw, 50 final
2) 0.1 mid term, 0.3 hw, 50 final
unlimited times

Even if you fucked up during the mid-term exam, you still have a chance to improve your grade in the final. Personally, I find the final exam questions to be more manageable overall.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for homework is definitely not heavy. What you need is self-study, practice, and more practice!

AND ONLY HAVE 4 MC QUESTIONS IN EXAM! 1 MC question was 10 MARKS out of 100 marks. and average student cannot get 3 mc right. Long questions very stingy with marks.

reviews.comment_teaching: I think the instructor does not know how to teach at all. He just taught some complicated maths knowledge for students who have a poor math foundation or have not learnt calculus before. However, you should attend all the tutorials taught by Phyllis Liang as she could consolidate students' calculus knoledge and explain each single steps for each questionsn clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading scheme in this semester.
Grading scheme 1: Homework 20%; Mid-term 30%; Final 50%.
Grading scheme 2: Homework 20%; Mid-term 10%; Final 70%.
reviews.comment_workload: There is about 2-3 homework for a month.Most of the answers can be found in the Internet.

在可以接受的範圍之内。

但是口音很重，這點在看錄像時尤爲嚴重。
reviews.comment_grading: 她們有特意把final exam設計得比midterm更簡單，並把原先的absolute grating改爲更友好的制度。
reviews.comment_workload: 自學就足夠了，只要每個星期做次練習就足夠了。

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is okay. One assignment every two weeks. But if you want to get A range, you need to spend many time to practice.

reviews.comment_teaching: Carries lots of blank paper. Solve problems from textbook instead of teaching the basics. I wish he could understand this course is mainly for students who have ni background in calculus like me. He does answer questions and responds to students in the following lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
There were two schemes this time. Because the mean for mid-term was 27, the grading was adjusted.

Scheme 1:
HW (20%)
Mid-term (30%)
Finals (50%)


Scheme 2:
HW (20%)
Mid-term (10%)
Finals (70%)

HW: 98% (my score)
Mid-term: 28.47 (mean)/ 6 (my score)
Finals: 59.95 (mean)/ 62 (my score)

Final grade:
Scheme 1: 52.55
Scheme 2: 63.75

I got C+ at the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 Homework in total. 16-22 questions. Questions can be found online and their solution videos. They’re of easy to medium difficulty. HW4 and HW5 were given right before and after maths mid-term, it was kinda rush.
All thanks to Khan Academy for helping me pass this!

Informed you within less than a day (attached) and so I missed it.

What I observed is that this course is required for most students, so if you have done some revisions, you are unlikely to get a grade that is below C range. Of coz hard to get A range too,

(So I get C from this course)
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork exercises per 1-2 weeks, which are complex and time-consuming. Recommend using math tools on the web. And the last exercises were EXTENDED to the date after the final exam.

reviews.comment_content: Integration and differentiation are not difficult, just some basic stuff. The content is very similar to 1013, but this one is easier.
reviews.comment_teaching: the teaching is boring, but his handwriting is pretty nice, you can skip all the lectures and just read those lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading: It is not too difficult to get a good grade, I got 76 on final exam and I got an A in this course

reviews.author: evvon
reviews.title: Give up. If you want to swap to Xie Peng, I encourage you. Give up.
reviews.comment_content: Dunno, I just attend the first few lessons and after all, I just watch youtube. Insane UST wants you to learn the DSE m1/m2 3-year syllabus in one semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: His accent is SHIT, totally SHIT. This is the main reason why I give up attending lectures. You know when his accent is distracting me from focusing on what he wrote.
reviews.comment_grading: Changed to relative grading, So good. Normally get B+, but it will be poor if it is absolute grading,
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload, One assignment per week, and unlimited attempts before the deadline.

reviews.author: Emmmaaa
reviews.comment_content: The teaching is satisfactory yet the whole course is so hard. If you are not really confident in mathematics, please spend more time in this course. You have to pay more effort in studying the relationship between numbers and especially differentiaion.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches not really bad but he was so annoying during exams. He called everyone's names continuously and this disturbs me. It's not possible for me to mute his mic as he might have important announcements. Yet, the tutorial is quite useful I think when many people got great improvements after attending them.
reviews.comment_grading: His grading is quite fair even though I have got poor grades in his course.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework every week and this is quite annoying when you know nothing about maths.

reviews.author: melodyloi1011
reviews.comment_content: It was very hard for students who know nothing about calculus. It was definitely not basic. The tutorials were way more useful than the lectures. But, no attendance was required for both lectures and tutorials. You could catch up by watching videos.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher taught with no passion. He spoke in such mono tone that I just attended one lecture in the whole semester.  However, the teaching assistant was quite good. She taught very clearly and neatly. Her notes were quite tidy and useful.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was somehow good because even I failed the final, I still didn’t get C range. As long as you have done all your homework, you could guarantee some basic marks. By the way, there was no mid term. So the final and your homework mark basically determined your whole grade of this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was just fine because there was just one homework on WEBWORK every week. The homework contained about ten questions each and with unlimited attempts. A good way for students who were bad at maths to earn marks.

reviews.author: Ian1017
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

However in my opinion, this course is definitely not in beginner's level. I had never learnt M1/M2 before and I couldn't understand anything during class, even my friend who had studied M1 during DSE couldn't loll.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Originally I was in Avery's class. His class was super boring as he was just copying his notes and wrote them on the whiteboard to teach us.
Then I swap to the same session as my friend's, which was taught by Qian. His accent was quite difficult to understand so basically me and my friends study by ourselves by looking up videos on YouTube, and we believe this is the best way.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was fine, at least there were online assignments which you can try hundreds and thousands of times to get the correct answers. Yet the mid term and final exams are difficult for me.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was fine. Remember to try to answer the online assignments until you get the correct answers to get the full marks out of it.

reviews.author: wave
reviews.comment_content: The content is similar to what you learnt in high school. The content includes functions, graphs, integrals, inequalities, and derivatives.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can hardly understand what the instructor is saying as I find his accent hard to hear. As a result, I didn't come to any lectures or tutorials. It's better to study with your friends. I understand more from my friends. The attendance is not taken so I think the lectures were just a waste of time.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is a bit of a gamble as it only includes the homework and final exam for the final score. If you choke on your final exam, your grade will drop as 75% of the final score is taken from your final exam. I did all the homework and I did well in the finals. I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light as there are only 9 webwork excercices you have to do in 1 term. I always did it with my friends and it usually take 2 hours to do as the questions are sometimes tricky. The workload is extremely light for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: Darryl
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives, and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus

The course itself is not particularly hard and you can study the entire course by yourself
reviews.comment_teaching: I didn't attend any of the lectures since attendance is not recorded. The ta, Phyllis is really good and you should attend her tutorials
reviews.comment_grading:
No midterm, no attendance
25% webwork 75% final
reviews.comment_workload: webwork every two weeks, there are unlimited attempts. So you don't have to worry about the assignments.

reviews.author: Peterson
reviews.title: Just study yourself
reviews.comment_content: "Basic" maths calculus up to the beginning of integration. 2 years of M2 in one semester. Lucky you!
reviews.comment_teaching: Horrible. The pronunciation of English is fucking terrible with filler words to actual words ratio at 1:1 (uhhhhhh...this uhhhhh...absolute uhhhhh..."nAmber"uhhhhh...) His handwriting is shit, his notes and graphs are unreadable.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% webwork (unlimited attempts and can copy)
75% final exam.

They fucking gave us the past paper of 2015, and say it was enough for us to revise. But the final this time came with a totally different format to that paper( this time no MC), and the difficulty has significantly increased like what the fuck. And no midterm means you will never know your level of understanding. Trust me, you may understand in lesson because their examples are easy shit, but reality they will just fuck you in the ass when you don't see it coming.

Oh yes, no calculators in exam, I need to square root some shit and I got fucked because of it.
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork every two weeks except for last few weeks where you get one every week. Just use Wolfram Alpha.

reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2.

reviews.author: GiRange
reviews.title: Much effort is needed
reviews.comment_content:
Most DSE M2 stuff but not include all.

<Week>
<1> Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
<2> Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
<3> Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
<4> Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
<5> Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
<6> Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
<7> Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
<8> Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
<9> Derivatives and graphs (4.3), L’Hôpital’s rule (4.4)
<10> Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
<11> Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
<12> Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
<13> Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)

The content is not really hard since all the topics come from the DSE syllabus. If you are an engine student, you should try your best to study this course. Otherwise, you will get into trouble when studying math1014 and math 2011. If you are a science student, you are glad that this may be your last math course at HKUST.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Qian is good at teaching. He’s from the Mainland, but his accent is clear and understandable. He uses handwritten notes instead of PowerPoint during lessons. That's great since the peace of the lesson will not be too fast because he wrote the note during the lesson with us. If you are paying attention in class, it's not too hard for you to learn calculus from scratch.

As for my TA Henry, his voice is depressing; however, he taught us some shortcuts on doing questions. That's useful since it helped me to shorten the time on doing a question. He also did WebWork with us step by step during tutorial. Once you have any questions, you can ask him during tutorial or send email to him. He will answer you ASAP.
reviews.comment_grading:
Better than expected honestly
Relative grading
25% for Homework(WebWork)
75% for Final exam
-----------------------------------------------------------------
My grade:
Homework: 95.56% (Mean: 92.51%)
Final exam: 81% (Mean: 42.17%)
Grade: A
The grading is fair since it uses a relative grading system. One of my friends get 41% in final and get a B grade too. So, never give up!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate. There is 1 WebWork per week on average. However, more practice is needed besides WebWork for me since I am not good at math. If you are not good at math, I suggest you do all exercises from DSE M2 book like me. It will help you so much.

Not really hard to achieve A+ if you have studied partial fraction and by part (content in MATH1014) as you can see in the exam paper.

Kinda not absolute grading.
69+ A-, 75+ A, 84+ A+

=> A+
Mean 3x/100

Reasonable workload, one assignment every two weeks.
No midterm, but the exam.

13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)

reviews.comment_teaching:
嗰system揀唔到我嘅instructors 所以就打係到。
首先, lecture方面，我係 Xu,Zili 同 Phyills教嘅。Professor Xu 雖然平時講嘢有d口音，但佢上堂前會做好多準備。佢平時上堂前會同大家溫一次上堂講過嘅嘢，然後全程都會寫notes。上佢堂我都覺得係ok嘅。然後Phyills嘅lecture notes 係十分有用，個人覺得最好唔好miss佢嘅堂，因為佢會係最短時間內令你大致上理解教嘅內容。但佢教嘅內容就相對Professor Xu 冇咁複雜。
Tutorial 方面，我自己就去過兩個，一個係Jiayi教嘅（唔肯定有冇串錯佢嘅名），一個係Phyills,同上面教lecture嘅係同一個人。Jiayi主要都係講返功課，我個人就比較少去，主要都係靠佢啲notes做功課。而Phyills嘅Tutorial 可以測試到自己嘅學習進度，因為佢會上堂叫你做佢出嘅練習，當然亦都會同功課有啲關係嘅。
reviews.comment_grading:
呢個course就拉curve嘅，睇你讀嗰陣好唔好彩，有冇咁多人同你一齊chur啫。我就覺得如果你上齊堂做齊asm就離合格唔遠嘅。
P.S.
WebWork marks: 25%
Final Marks ：75%
reviews.comment_workload: 其實就得約10個WebWork做，頭幾個webwork都唔難，自己努力吓就做得完。之後嗰啲都會有Tutorial 教你做所以都唔會好stressful.

reviews.author: Milktea
reviews.title: JUST WATCH YOUTUBE MATH TUTORIALS
reviews.comment_content:
25% Webwork
75% Final Exam (no midterm)

The content is a bit much for people who have not taken M1 or M2 in DSE, but is manageable

The topics may seem unfamiliar and scary at first, but you will be fine once you understand the method of calculation

Topics covered in the final exam:
1. Derive the inverse function of a given function
2. Limits (xc→  and x→infinity)
3. To show the existence of a root by using the intermediate value theorem
4. Find the derivative from the definition
5. Chain rule
6. Implicit differentiation and the tangent line
7. Rate of change
8. Locate the relative maximum and relative minimum
9. L'Hopital Rule
11. Curve Sketching
12. Indefinite integrals and definite integrals
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teachers: Xu Zili, Li Jiayi (Regina)
- TL;DR: both are bad

The most useful math lessons are from mathvengers, which is compulsory for DSE students with level 3 or 4 in maths

Xu Zili: You won't hear what he is saying in the lecture hall cuz he speaks very softly. The fact that he has a heavy Chinese accent doesn't help. He overcomplicates every single topic and it is hard to keep up with his pace. I just skipped all his lectures cuz there is no need for attendance.

Regina: Regina teaches a small class every week. I could not hear her speak cuz she does not use a mic, she writes on a whiteboard with black markers that have no ink, could hardly see what she wrote. I just attended one lesson from her.

I just took the lessons from mathvengers, the year 2 students teach better than the teachers at UST

If you want to learn the topics efficiently, just watch youtube calculus tutorials
reviews.comment_grading:

I got the full mark for webwork and I had over 40 marks in the final exam, my final grade was B, it was better than I expected so I have no complaints. Big thanks to the organic chemistry tutor for the math videos

reviews.comment_teaching:

A+ for TA TSANG, Henry Pak Yeung
I skipped lectures of prof since almost the end of differentiation and the start of integration. I only attended the Supp lecture (Henry) and tutorials of LIANG.

Personally, I think prof is not my learning style bcuz he focuses so much on proving things...... and sometimes go through the ppt too fast. How can I do implicit differentiation just after introducing what differentiation is ????? Man, I just know what is chain rule and power rule?? HOW?

TSANG, Henry Pak Yeung IS SO GOOD!!!!!!!
Makes funny and daddy jokes and tell us some interesting things in ust, and makes the math lesson in a good atmosphere. And he explained all the things so good, all in detail. Give us many useful tips for the final. Makes math fun even for a math idiot like me. Want to see him in 1014 next sem <3

reviews.author: Sirob
reviews.comment_content:
1. Functions
The first month covers the properties of different functions, finding domain and inverse functions
2. Limits
Then, the course move on to how to find the limit of functions, some important limits to remember and concepts of asymptotes
Note that L'Hopitals Rule will be covered after derivative
3. Derivative
This part cover basic rules of derivative, chain rule, how to find the related rate using derivative
4. Graph sketching
This part is hybrid of the part 1,2,3 mentioned above, it cover local&global extrema and how to sketch the graph for functions
5. Integral
Last part of the course is integral, which covers Riemann sum and indefinite& definite integral

As someone who failed this course once, I think the workload is heavy for people did not take m2 in DSE or people who are not good at maths like me.
You have to make sure you are clear about the concepts in every week, do not try to rush the syllabus within few days or you may fail the course
reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.author: mc_cch
reviews.title: Hard to follow
reviews.comment_content:
"Basic" calculus   !?     lol
1. Trigonometric functions
2. Log
3. Limits
4. Derivatives
5. Integration

Be careful about the 'Derivatives' & the 'Integration' parts as they are quite difficult !

But you may become happy once you figured out the difference between 'log' and 'natural log' (e).

Note 1: L'Hôpital's rule is useful
Note 2: some people may get confused with the correct name of  L'Hôpital's rule. (NOT  The l'hospital rule, the hopital rule, l'hopital rule )
Note 3: Hôpital is a French word, which L' means 'the' in English
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty nice, as he is friendly and patient.

But he taught very fast, so for those students without Calculus background, you should pay attention to his every single step..............
Many students skipped his lecture because not everyone could follow what he was doing....................

For the TA (Walter Chan), I think his notes and course materials used in the lessons were quite useful, so please do not skip the tutorial lessons !

Both of them could understand English, Cantonese and Mandarin, so feel free to ask them.
reviews.comment_grading:
There was a special arrangement for this semester, so the final exam was done on Canvas.

HW: 25%   nice~~~ :)
Final: 75%

Grade:
HW: unknown %, as I didn't answer all the questions correctly
Final:  12/22 (54.5%)     (divided into 6 parts)

Overall:  B  (Fair la)
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to complete your homework (Webwork)  almost every week. They cover the basic mathematic and the topic you leaned. Some questions are EXTREMELY hard, so:
    1. Do form a Whatsapp/ Signal group
    2. Do send a email and ask the prof./ TA
    3. Do help your classmates
    4. Do go to the Math Support Centre (MSC) (Website: https://www.math.ust.hk/~support/index.html) as the TAs would offer assistance to you.

If you really want to get a good grade, you ought to get WELLLLLL prepared BEFORE the lessons. Because I couldn't follow well in the last two month. Also, I strongly recommend you to download all the materials form the TA's website (e.g. https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/) and practice more before the exam....... Good luck!

reviews.comment_teaching: Horrible experience. If I only listen to his teaching, I think there is no chance I will pass this course. He really good at let people feeling sleepy, but not good at teaching students understanding the concept.
reviews.comment_grading: If you finish all the webwork, then you just need to work hard a little bit to familiar with different kind of exercises. Then, you have nothing to worry about this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was quiet light since you only need to finish the webwork every week or two week and them you can obtain all the marks form the webwork. Most of the question can be google from the internet, only few of the questions require little bit effort.

reviews.author: arianator
reviews.title: Hell for people who didn't study M1
reviews.comment_content:
Topics
Number, inequalities and absolutes, basic functions and graphs, composite functions

Exponential functions, trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions

Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws

Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change

Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions

Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions

Rates of change problems, related rates

Maximum and minimum values

Derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule

Curve sketching, optimization problems

Antiderivatives, areas

Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

Indefinite integrals and net change, the substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quian has a better accent than other professors. He is very nice. He explained the lecture notes and every equations. However, these are not helpful for the exam. These explanation are suitable for math lovers.

As for tutor, I recommend Walter Chan as he explain the questions and theories very clearly.

To be honest, I skipped 60% of the lecture and tutor and study myself. Practices are much more important than attending the lesson for MATH if you are only concern about the grade. In this case, youtubers can help you a lot.

https://www.khanacademy.org/math/ap-calculus-ab/ab-integration-new/ab-6-1/v/introduction-to-integral-calculus

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1xATmTI-YY8&list=PL0o_zxa4K1BWYThyV4T2Allw6zY0jEumv
reviews.comment_grading:
It definitely not a good grade course.
Mean of my session is 12.4over 22
25% mark for webwork and 75% mark for the final exam
Me 100% done & correct in webwork, final:10/22
Finally get C+
5/22 + 100% correct webwork can pass the course.
So if u didn't perform well in the final, most likely u get a F
reviews.comment_workload:
9 webwork and final exam.
As I didn't study M1, 1 webwork costs 4-6 hours. Sometimes a whole afternoon. HELL

reviews.author: a877493889y
reviews.comment_content:
Topics
1 Number, inequalities and absolutes, basic functions and graphs, composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)

2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)

3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)

4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and rates of change (2.7)

5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of trigonometric functions (3.3)

6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)

7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)

8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)

9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), L’Hôpital’s rule (4.4)

10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)

11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas(5.1)

12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus(5.3)

13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching:
A quite nice professor for my feeling, not sure for the teaching quality as skipped all the lecture.

For tutor, recommend Walter Chan.

To be honest, I skipped 90% of the lecture and tutor and study myself. Because I think practices are much more important than attending the lesson for MATH if you are only concern about the grade.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% webwork + 75% exam (No mid-term this sem)

Exam: 18 MC questions, 21 points in total

My final grade: A-
Webwork: 100% (unlimited attempt, can google)
Exam: 16/21

No attendance
reviews.comment_workload: quite heavy as there are 2 lecture and 2 tutor each week and you need to absorb all the content. Also as a beginner to calculus, you need to pre-study yourself and keep practice practice & practices to get A range.

reviews.author: Louis P
reviews.title: Killer course in HKUST
reviews.comment_content:
So hard for the student who haven't study M1/M2 before
About calculus and very difficult for student with no M1M2 background
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite general
it is important of self-learning.
Remember to attend the tutorial even you skip the lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
it is important for you to finish all the assignment
Also mid-term and final is is important for you grade
Don't miss your webwork
I failed once because not complete all the assignment
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite low
But remember to finish all the webwork
ask TA for help if you have question

reviews.author: 元荃古道
reviews.title: Only attend tutorial is enough
reviews.comment_content: Only attend the tutorial is good enough, as AV ching is only proving the differential and integral. Also, the knowledge required for the exam will be all taught in the tutorial.
reviews.comment_teaching: The tutor is pretty good, you can learn through watching demonstrations and doing exercise yourselves during the class
reviews.comment_grading: This semester did not have mid term exam, so our grade is mainly based on the exam (70%), the rest 30% is the homework. The exam is just mc questions, if you are lucky, you probably can get a good grade without revision.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload, just some basic homework.

reviews.author: soysauce
reviews.title: alright for ex-m2
reviews.comment_content: I studied DSE M2 for form 4 (failed and dropped) and got basic concepts introduced in lectures with a bit of effort. Used the M2A New Century Mathematics book (for DSE) to go over course content. The book i used generally covers everything except for inverse functions (?). This course should be difficult to understand if you don't have any calculus background. For revision, find exercises that gradually go up in difficulty (from tutor's website etc.).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Inconsistent teaching pace. Professor tries to be slow for more difficult concepts but all concepts are difficult. Sometimes time is wasted at the beginning of the lectures to wait for people to come into zoom (~10mins to go from 30 people to 50 people)(attendance is not mandatory and zoom recordings are uploaded after each lecture). His class notes are uploaded. They are aesthetically pleasing and can help you understand what he said in lectures (I did not use them much).

TUTORIALS ARE USEFUL (had Walter Chan)
reviews.comment_grading:
Got A-. Grade from hw and final exam. I had 100% for hw. For exam got ~5pts above the mean for my exam group (students were split into 2-3 zoom meeting rooms for exam)(total ~24 marks).

Exam was split into 6 parts (a few questions for each part) and we got to see our marks after each part was submitted. No calculator allowed, questions were generally easier than hw. Good if you remember definitions and remember how to do basic math.
reviews.comment_workload:
All online work. Amount seemed moderate in the beginning but gradually spiraled out of control. New assignments created before the deadline of the previous one(s) ensure that you will always be in a state of worry. Always had some unfinished assignment at any given point during the semester. Last assignment was due on the last day of 'study break' with the previous assignment due just days before.

Questions can get pretty insane. At least we had unlimited attempts to get the assignments 100% correct. Achievable with patience.

reviews.author: 一點寒芒

reviews.comment_teaching:
The style of teaching was very boring.
You can totally learn by yourself under the situation of the online teaching mode.
reviews.comment_grading:
No mid-term examination
Final examination (all are multiple choices questions)
The grade is appropriate because I didn't have a solid structure of mathematics.
Grade:  B- (above the mean around 0.x ~ 1 )
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload would be not high if you have already learnt M1/M2.
But for me, I spent 2 weeks to review all the concepts and did the exercises before the examination.

reviews.author: CCC_ccc
reviews.comment_content: For students who went to high school in Taiwan, it would be really easy cuz almost all the content were taught in high school. (Of course, if you haven't study since finishing GSAT, do not expect to 躺著拿分)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Did not take attendance.
The prof is nice, but I learned everything from slides and notes provieded by the TA,  not from the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final : 70%
Assignment : 30%

The final exam was not difficult. It should be easy to get good grades.
I got 18/22 in the fianl exam, 100/100 in webwork. Got an A finally.
(One of my friends got 19/22,100/100, also got A.)
reviews.comment_workload:
There were around 10 assignment this sem.
You can use the materials on the TA's website to practice more if you want (It's really useful cuz I think the assignments were too easy. Also, you can understand the concepts better from them.)

The prof said there used to be a midterm exam but this time we didn't have one because we were taking online sem.

(Sorry for my poor English if you find this hard to understand :( )

reviews.author: fangzi
reviews.comment_content: the former part is easy and the latter part ifs a bit new, talking about integrals, L'Hopital Rule, etc.

teaching sucks, but whenever you ask her questions privately she will answer you with patience.

you can totally learn by yourself regardless of who is teaching to be honest by reviewing the slides and necessary Wikipedia, you can make it.
